concept.title: Topic bodies
concept.shortdesc: While all the information types have the same elements for title, short description, and prolog, they each allow different content in their body.

conbody.p: Generic topics allow section-level elements (section and example), and also block-level elements (paragraphs, lists, and so on). You can add them in any mix, but generally you should make sure that content after a section is also in a section: if you follow a section with a standalone paragraph, for example, the paragraph will look to readers as if it is part of the section before it.
Concept topics allow much the same as topics, except they enforce the rule that, after sections, you can only add more sections and examples.

Task topics provide a very specific structure, with a set of task-specific elements that describe the prerequisites, context, steps, result, and post-requirements of a task. You can also add an example at the end.
Reference topics have some specific structures, like properties and syntax sections, but also allow some common block-level content (tables) as well as generic sections and examples.
